div.p: Columbia, sitting in a chair bearing the seal of the United States, holds 1860 presidential candidate Stephen Douglas over her knee and beats him with a multi-tailed whip labeled "News from Maine," scolding him for supporting the "Nebraska Bill" (the Kansas-Nebraska Act). An elderly man, labeled "Uncle Sam," observing at left, encourages Columbia to beat Douglas harder. In 1860, Douglas was criticized for the relatively unusual practice of making nationwide campaign tours and was accused of making a campaign visit to New England and New York under the ruse of visiting his mother. In this cartoon, likely a sequel to another cartoon entitled "Taking the Stump, or Stephen in Search of His Mother," Douglas has found his mother (Columbia, the female embodiment of the United States), and she is very disappointed in him.
Published by Currier & Ives, 152 Nassau St. N.Y.
Entered according to act of Congress in the year 1860, by Currier & Ives, in the Clerk's Office of the Dist. Court for the Southn. Dist. of N.Y.
You have been a bad boy Steve, ever since you had anything to do with that Nebraska Bill and have made a great deal of trouble in the family and now I'll pay you for it.—
Oh! Marm let me off this time and I'll never do so any more.

div.head: Uncle Sam.
div.p: That's right! Columbia lay it on to him, for he richly deserves it, give him the Stripes till he sees Stars.—
